item.title: Resumen de ‘Melania’, el documental sobre la primera dama de Estados Unidos
item.description: La película, que cuenta con Melania Trump como productora, aborda sus raíces migrantes, el amor por su madre y su estilo, pero hay pocas revelaciones.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik

item.title: Quote of the Day: For Bobsledding Mothers, Life Is a Blur
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 31, 2026.

item.title: How Europe Is Moving to Reduce Dependence on Trump
item.description: Since President Trump made threats about Greenland, the continent’s leaders have debated the rapid deterioration of U.S. ties in policy papers and at dinner.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Lara Jakes, Steven Erlanger and Jim Tankersley

media:content.media:credit: Ronny Hartmann/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: European leaders on Monday at a summit in Hamburg, Germany. Although they are verbally pushing harder than ever against President Trump, they are still struggling to bolster their statements with action.

item.title: U.S. Allies Are Drawing Closer to China, but on Beijing’s Terms
item.description: As Washington unsettles its partners, Beijing is reaping diplomatic gains, without backing down on human rights, trade or security.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Berry Wang

media:content.media:credit: Pool photo by Kin Cheung
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain in Shanghai on Friday. Mr. Starmer became the first British leader to visit China since 2018.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 31, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 31, 2026.

item.title: Draft Epstein Indictment Accused Him of Crimes Against More Than a Dozen Girls
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein, who ended up pleading to a much lesser state charge, told one victim that bad things could happen to her if she talked, the 2007 document said.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett

media:content.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In 2019, the F.B.I. announced new sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier.

item.title: Evil Spirits
item.description: Nick Maritz’s debut puzzle is full of thrills and spills.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Jewel Samad/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Prepare to be spun around a few times in this puzzle.

item.title: ‘Melania’ Review: 20 Stage-Managed Days in the Life of the First Lady
item.description: Directed by Brett Ratner, the documentary shows a woman deeply concerned with her appearance who rarely lets us behind her facade.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Police Report Backs Activist’s Account in Clash With ICE Agent Near Chicago
item.description: A new report from a police department outside of Chicago sheds light on a rare battery charge brought against an ICE agent after a fight with an activist.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim

media:content.media:credit: Carlos Javier Ortiz for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators gathered near an immigration detention center in Broadview, Ill., to protest ICE raids nationwide earlier this month.

item.title: Trump Officials Bypass Congress to Push Billions in Weapons Aid to Israel
item.description: The move was the third time the Trump administration has tried to expedite arms shipments to Israel by going around the review process for weapons sales.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong

media:content.media:credit: Gonzalo Fuentes/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The weapons aid included Apache attack helicopters and combat land vehicles.

item.title: Release of Three Million Epstein Pages Falls Short, Survivors Say
item.description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, told reporters on Friday that “there’s a hunger or a thirst for information that I do not think will be satisfied by the review of these documents.”
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Michael Gold and Mike Baker

media:content.media:credit: J. Scott Applewhite/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, addressed reporters after the Justice Department released more Epstein files.

item.title: She Called Mamdani a ‘Terrorist Lover.’ Did She Deserve to Be Promoted?
item.description: Inna Vernikov, a Republican city councilwoman, was named to help lead a task force to fight antisemitism. She later apologized for her remark about Mayor Zohran Mamdani.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Sally Goldenberg

media:content.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Councilwoman Inna Vernikov on Friday apologized for comments she made about Mayor Zohran Mamdani that she acknowledged were “inflammatory.”

item.title: After Bovino Leaves, Minnesotans Search for Signs of Change in Crackdown
item.description: Arrests were continuing, according to residents who have tracked the immigration crackdown in the Twin Cities, but some people observed fewer clashes.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Julie Bosman

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Agents stopped a car in Minneapolis on Thursday.

item.title: F.B.I. Presentation Outlines Allegations Against Powerful Men
item.description: A 21-page slide presentation summarized the agency’s investigations into Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Matthew Goldstein and Steve Eder

item.title: 6 Missing as Search Continues for Boat Off the Coast of Massachusetts
item.description: Searchers recovered one body after the Lily Jean, a 72-foot fishing vessel, issued an emergency alert on Friday morning, the U.S. Coast Guard said.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: David Goldman/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A fishing boat that left from Gloucester, Mass., on Friday was reported missing off the coast of Massachusetts, the U.S. Coast Guard said.

item.title: Trump Names ‘Data Nerd’ to Lead Labor Statistics Agency
item.description: The decision to nominate Brett Matsumoto, a career government economist, came six months after the president fired the previous commissioner.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump fired the last Bureau of Labor Statistics commissioner because he said the monthly jobs report numbers had been “rigged.”

item.title: Can You Teach an A.I. Model to Be Good?
item.description: Amanda Askell, the in-house philosopher at Anthropic, joins “Hard Fork” to discuss the company’s new “Claude Constitution” and why training the company’s A.I. model on ethics is an important task.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara Was Always a Delight
item.description: The Emmy-winning actress was especially adept at playing women who had been cast off but maintained an inflated sense of self, always with a great comedic payoff.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

media:content.media:credit: 20th Century Fox
media:content.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in “Home Alone,” the movie in which many first saw her comic gifts.

item.title: Trump Officials Move to Double Number of H-2B Guest Visas This Year
item.description: It was a rare move by the Trump administration to expand a foreign worker program, amid a sweeping effort to drastically cut immigration.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Giorgio Viera/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A landscaper working outside Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s private club and residence, in Palm Beach, Fla., in 2022. Mr. Trump has used the H-2B visa program to hire cooks, housekeepers and waiters at his properties.

item.title: Trump Called for ‘De-Escalation’ in Minneapolis. It Didn’t Last Long.
item.description: President Trump has offered dueling messages on the crisis in Minneapolis, part of a pattern of dialing back his rhetoric only to change again if the political winds are shifting.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office on Friday.

item.title: Could the Hudson River Freeze Over?
item.description: New York City is icy and cold right now, but you’re probably not going to be able to walk to New Jersey any time soon.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff and Joel Eastwood

media:content.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ice floating in the New York Bay from the East and Hudson Rivers continues to affect ferry operations in Downtown Manhattan.

item.title: Here’s What to Know About the Millions of Pages of Epstein Documents
item.description: Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche signaled that this would be the last major release of files related to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The Justice Department released millions of new pages related to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Epstein Offered Prince Andrew a Meeting With a Russian Woman, Emails Show
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was stripped of his royal titles last year after new disclosures showed the extent of his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

media:content.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Britain’s former Prince Andrew at the Sandringham estate in England in 2022.

item.title: After ICE Took Liam Conejo Ramos, 2 Students From Same School Enter Detention
item.description: The school’s principal said he brought two children to federal custody at the request of their mother, who was detained. Last week, another student, Liam Conejo Ramos, was picked up by immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh

media:content.media:credit: Seth Herald/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Valley View Elementary School in Columbia Heights, Minn., last week. Over two dozen parents and caregivers tied to the school have been detained in the Trump administration’s immigration sweeps.

item.title: U.N. Says It’s in Danger of Financial Collapse Because of Members’ Unpaid Dues
item.description: The world body warned it would run out of money by July and have to close its New York headquarters if countries, namely the United States, did not pay annual dues that amount to billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The General Assembly in September. The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, sent a letter to the ambassadors of all 196 member states on Thursday saying, “I cannot overstate the urgency of the situation we now face.”

item.title: Archivos Epstein: Trump y Einstein son mencionados en un documento de pistas recibidas por el FBI
item.description: Este verano, los investigadores federales recopilaron un resumen de las acusaciones contra Trump que habían llegado a través de la línea pública de denuncias de la agencia. El Times no ha corroborado las acusaciones.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Confessore

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente Trump fue mencionado en más de una decena de pistas recibidas por el Buró Federal de Investigaciones en relación con Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Where to Watch Catherine O’Hara’s Best Performances, From ‘Beetlejuice’ to ‘Best in Show’
item.description: Her characters were as varied as they were eccentric and lovable. These are some of the best.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

media:content.media:credit: Pop TV
media:content.media:description: Catherine O’Hara won a best lead actress Emmy for her role as the down-and-out former millionaire Moira Rose in the sitcom “Schitt’s Creek.”

item.title: What to Know About the ‘Abortion Clinic’ Law Being Used to Charge Don Lemon
item.description: The Trump administration used a federal law prohibiting blockades of abortion clinics and places of worship to charge Mr. Lemon and others in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Madeleine Hordinski for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An anti-abortion protest outside a women’s health clinic in Bristol, Va., in 2023. The Trump administration has repurposed a 1994 law that was used to shield women’s health clinics from disruptive blockades.

item.title: Jeff Bezos’s Rocket Company Blue Origin Pauses Space Tourism to Focus on the Moon
item.description: The New Shepard rocket from Blue Origin, which brought 92 people on trips to the edge of space, will cease flying for at least two years as the company prioritizes NASA contracts.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Minneapolis Mayor: Without Videos, ‘We’d All Be Living in a Lie’
item.description: Lulu Garcia-Navarro, co-host of “The Interview,” spoke to Minneapolis’s mayor, Jacob Frey, about the the killings of Renee Good and Alex Pretti, protests over aggressive federal actions and why fighting ICE isn’t just his city’s fight.

item.title: Senate Passes Deal to Fund Government and Negotiate ICE Limits
item.description: Democrats agreed to fund the Department of Homeland Security for two weeks while they negotiate with President Trump on restricting his immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A rally in Minneapolis on Friday. The Senate passed a spending package to continue funding the Department of Homeland Security for two weeks while Democrats negotiate with President Trump on restrictions to the administration’s immigration enforcement measures.

item.title: Grand Jury Hears Evidence on Brooklyn Power Broker
item.description: Brooklyn federal prosecutors have been conducting a corruption investigation into Frank Carone, who served as Mayor Eric Adams’s chief of staff.
item.dc:creator: William K. Rashbaum and Dana Rubinstein
item.category: Eric Adams Federal Corruption Case (24 CR 556)

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Frank Carone has been under federal investigation since 2024, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

item.title: Bad Bunny Deserves Album of the Year at the Grammys
item.description: What makes an Album of the Year? Popcast hosts Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli are rooting for Bad Bunny’s “Debí Tirar Mas Fotos.”

item.title: Judge Weighs Trump’s Removal of Slavery Markers From George Washington’s House
item.description: The administration has ordered that further changes be made to Independence National Historical Park, according to internal National Park Service documents obtained by The New York Times
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz and Maxine Joselow

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Blank walls where signs about slavery were removed from Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia last week.

item.title: Protesters Denounce Trump Immigration Tactics in ‘National Shutdown’
item.description: Demonstrators rallied across the country, leaving school and work and closing businesses in a show of solidarity with Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao, Orlando Mayorquín, Nate Schweber, Rhianwen Watkins and Mark Bonamo

media:content.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A demonstration in Foley Square in downtown Manhattan on Friday.

item.title: ICE Expands Power of Agents to Arrest People Without Warrants
item.description: An internal memo changed the standard from whether people are unlikely to show up for hearings to whether they could leave the scene.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz and Charlie Savage

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents attempted to raid a home in Minneapolis earlier this week.

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry’ Fans Want the Fleece. They’ll Be Able to Get It.
item.description: American and Canadian “Heated Rivalry” fans are hot for the jacket worn by the character Shane Hollander.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: Escape to Alcatraz: Coyote Swims a Mile in Search of New Turf
item.description: The coyote struggled onto the rocky shore this month. It is the first documented coyote on Alcatraz since the island was transferred to the National Park Service in 1972.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A coyote swam ashore at Alcatraz Island this month. It is the first documented coyote presence there since the island was transferred to the National Park Service in 1972.

item.title: Justice Dept. Opens Civil Rights Inquiry Into Minneapolis Killing
item.description: Also, Kevin Warsh is Trump’s pick to lead the Fed. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial for Alex Pretti in Minneapolis.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The Canadian actress’s career spanned decades and genres, including memorable roles in “Home Alone” and “Schitt’s Creek.”

media:content.media:credit: Bonnie Schiffman/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Catherine O’Hara photographed in 1986 in Los Angeles.

item.title: Musk and Epstein Exchanged Emails About Visiting One Another, Documents Show
item.description: Mr. Musk has tried to put distance between himself and the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, but emails show the two were on friendly terms.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Sharon LaFraniere and Ryan Mac

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Elon Musk at the Kennedy Center in Washington in November.

item.title: Trump’s Immigration Push Fractures Republican Party
item.description: The party was mostly unified on the issue not long ago, but splinters are everywhere now.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis last week.

item.title: Trump’s Lawsuit Against I.R.S. Creates ‘Enormous Conflict of Interest’
item.description: The president is demanding that the federal government pay him at least $10 billion over the unauthorized disclosure of his tax returns during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump created what legal experts called an unparalleled situation of federal agencies facing a lawsuit from the head of the executive branch.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, Actress in ‘Home Alone’ and ‘Schitt’s Creek,’ Dies at 71
item.description: The Emmy-winning comedian Catherine O’Hara, best known for her roles in “Home Alone,” “Schitt’s Creek” and “Beetlejuice,” and as a member of the influential Canadian sketch comedy series “SCTV,” died at the age of 71.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna

media:content.media:credit: Pop TV
media:content.media:description: “Schitt’s Creek” depicted a family forced to decamp to a small town after losing its fortune. From left: Dan Levy, Ms. O’Hara, Annie Murphy and Eugene Levy.

item.title: Death Toll During New York City Cold Snap Rises to 13
item.description: The growing number of deaths comes amid heightened concern about Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s handling of last weekend’s winter storm and the aftermath.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri and Dana Rubinstein

media:content.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Junction playground in Queens where the body of one victim was found.

item.title: Emails Show Warm Relationship Between Epstein and Richard Branson
item.description: The two men’s relationship was known, and a photo of Mr. Branson had been on display in Mr. Epstein’s Upper East Side townhouse.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport

media:content.media:credit: U.S. Justice Department
media:content.media:description: Richard Branson, left, and Jeffrey Epstein in an undated image released by the Justice Department in December.

item.title: Bruce Springsteen Takes the Stage as Minneapolis Residents Take to the Streets
item.description: For a second week, residents demonstrated against Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s incursion into their city. And Bruce Springsteen made a surprise appearance at a benefit concert.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson and Jesse McKinley

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Thousands of demonstrators poured into central Minneapolis for the second Friday in a row.

item.title: Updates: Millions of Pages of Epstein Documents Released
item.description: The release of files, videos and photographs from the federal inquiry into Jeffrey Epstein is the largest to date, and the final one planned by the Justice Department. Times reporters are sifting through the material.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Uma Sanghvi/The Palm Beach Post, via Associated Press
